page.title: 18CHANGING TIMES
page.content: In 1905 Kingsland had a population of 910. The village was lit by oil lamps which were lit manually every evening and extinguished next morning. The school had a roll of 150 pupils and the chief crops were hops, wheat, beans, turnips, barley, apples and pears. The village comprised 7 hamlets, West Town and Longford were the main village, with surrounding hamlets of Aston, Street, Shirl Heath (the old spelling), Cobnash and Lawton. By 1925 the population was 901. The living for the Rector of Kingsland was one of the wealthiest in the county, being worth Â£872. In 1945 the population was 914 and by this time there was a regular bus service to Leominster and Kington. The population in 1985 is 975. People had larger families in years gone by, with 8, 10 and even 22 children.
